questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumor in the older population. However, in contrast to this patient's rough, patchy lesions, it manifests as darkly pigmented papules or plaques that are soft, sharply demarcated, and appear greasy, wax-like, and “stuck-on.” Also, the lesions tend to involve the trunk, back of the hands, face and neck, and forearms, rather than the scalp.
Image Description:

Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)

Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are the most common skin tumors and occur on areas of skin exposed to sun. Given his former occupation, this patient is at increased risk of developing BCCs. However, in contrast to this patient's lesions, which manifest as erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques, BCCs present as pearly, indurated, and nodular lesions with a rolled border and a central depression (crater) with ulceration.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

While keratoacanthomas tend to occur in older patients who have had chronic sun exposure, such as this patient, they manifest as a round erythematous nodule with a central crater that grows rapidly, usually within weeks to months. In this patient, the multiple erythematous lesions with scales found on the scalp are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.

These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

D) INCORRECT:

Tinea capitis affects the scalp and manifests as round, scaly plaques with broken hair shafts or alopecia in the affected areas. Although this patient has mild itching, tinea capitis is usually associated with intense pruritus. Also, tinea capitis mainly affects small children and generally occurs in areas that contain hair follicles, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this 68-year-old bald man.
Image Description:

Localization: scalp
Primary lesion: nodule
Description: slightly elevated, reddened, papular, and pustular nodule with scaling and hair loss, caused by the dermatophyte Microsporum gypseum

E) CORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that occurs on sun-exposed skin (e.g., the scalp, face, ears, dorsal aspects of the hands or arms) and predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age. The lesions typically grow back after they are scraped off. Initially, actinic keratosis manifests as small lesions with a central scale and a rough surface, giving them a sandpaper-like texture on palpation. Later, the lesions may grow and become erythematous and scaly, as seen in this patient. The risk of progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma depends on the degree of epithelial dysplasia, but it is < 1% per year. Occasionally, hyperkeratosis may turn preexisting actinic keratosis lesions into cutaneous horns.

Actinic keratosis is usually a clinical diagnosis, although for lesions that are ≥ 1 cm, grow rapidly, or do not respond to treatment, a biopsy is necessary to distinguish it from squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment options include cryotherapy for isolated lesions, or 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod, or photodynamic therapy in patients with multiple lesions.
Image Description:

Frontal and parietal scalp of a male older adult

Multiple, partially confluent, hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules of different size are visible. Some of these lesions have scaling, and some are covered in yellow to black-brown crusts.

These findings are characteristic of actinic keratosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Bowen disease is commonly associated with sun exposure and may be similar in appearance to this patient's lesion. However, it usually manifests as a solitary lesion rather than the multiple ill-defined, confluent lesions seen on this patient's scalp. While Bowen disease cannot be entirely excluded without pathologic examination, based on the appearance of the lesions, another diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Amelanotic melanomas are associated with UV exposure and may be difficult to recognize, but they usually manifest as a pink or red macule, plaque, or nodule. Multiple erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques with a rough texture suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.
questions.hint: The scalp is covered with telangiectasias, light brown papules, and erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques. This condition is the result of chronic, unprotected sun exposure (e.g., from working outdoors).

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of white lesions in her mouth that she first noticed 5 days ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy. She has asthma treated with theophylline, inhaled β-adrenergic agonists, and corticosteroids. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Oral examination shows white plaques on the buccal mucosa and hard palate that are firmly adherent and cannot be scraped off. She has no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin is the first-line therapy for oropharyngeal candidiasis. This patient uses inhaled corticosteroids, which are a known risk factor for developing oral candidiasis. However, candidiasis is identified by its ability to be easily scraped off. The lesions in this patient's mouth are strongly adherent, making leukoplakia a more likely diagnosis. Additionally, this patient lacks other common symptoms of candidiasis, including pain while eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth.

B) CORRECT:

Biopsy of the lesions is the next best step in the management of leukoplakia, which most commonly affects the oral cavity. While leukoplakia is by itself a benign lesion, it predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma. Up to 30% of leukoplakia lesions progress to carcinoma depending on appearance, demography, and follow-up time. Because of this, it is important to biopsy leukoplakia lesions to check for signs of dysplasia.

Treatment consists of smoking cessation, cryotherapy, laser ablation, or surgical excision if the lesion persists.
Image Description:

Oral cavity

Well-defined white plaques with irregular borders can be seen bilaterally on the mucosa of the soft palate.
These patches cannot be scraped off with gauze.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids would be useful for the management of aphthous stomatitis. These “canker sores” have a round to oval, crater-like appearance on yellowish-grey base and erythematous margins, unlike this patient's presentation of white plaques.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision may be needed if the lesions persist following more conservative treatment. It would not be the first-line therapy or diagnostic tool.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking cessation is indicated in the long-term health maintenance of this patient. However, it would not directly help with the diagnosis or management of leukoplakia, and more immediate steps need to be taken.

F) INCORRECT:

A culture of the lesions would be appropriate if there was a concern for oropharyngeal candidiasis. However, candidiasis can be identified by its ability to be easily scraped off. The lesions in this patient's mouth are strongly adherent, making leukoplakia a more likely diagnosis. Additionally, this patient lacks other common symptoms of candidiasis, including pain while eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth.

G) INCORRECT:

Monospot test would be used to test for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which can cause oral hairy leukoplakia. This condition also manifests as white painless plaques that cannot be scraped off. However, they tend to occur on the lateral edges of the tongue as opposed to the buccal mucosa and hard palate as seen in this patient.

Note that the EBV serology test is the diagnostic test of choice for EBV infection, as the monospot test has a high risk of false positive and false negative results.
questions.hint: This patient has white plaques of the oral mucosa that cannot be scraped off, which is typical of leukoplakia. Cigarette smoking is a known risk factor for this condition.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician with a 4-month history of recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of his hands. When he scrapes off the crusts, they reappear after a few days. The lesions are mildly pruritic and occasionally burn. He works as a landscaper. A photograph of his right hand is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While keratoacanthomas tend to occur on the face, neck, arms, or hands in individuals who have had an extensive history of sun exposure, such as this patient, they manifest as a round erythematous nodule with a central crater that grows rapidly, usually within weeks to months. The patchy crusts on this patient's hands that have been recurring for 4 months are not consistent with keratoacanthoma.
Image Description:

An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.

These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

B) INCORRECT:

Sporotrichosis results from infection with Sporothrix schenckii, which is commonly found on vegetation and garden soil and is typically transmitted by the prick of a thorn. While this patient's occupation as a landscaper puts him at risk of contracting this disease, sporotrichosis manifests initially as a papule at the site of inoculation, which often ulcerates. Subsequently, subcutaneous nodules and ulcers develop as the fungus spreads proximally along the lymphatic vessels (nodular ascending lymphangitis). This patient's recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of his hands are not consistent with sporotrichosis.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) are the most common skin tumors and occur on areas of skin exposed to sun, especially the face. Given his occupation, this patient is at increased risk of developing BCCs. However, in contrast to this patient's lesions, which are erythematous, hyperkeratotic plaques, BCCs manifest as pearly, indurated, and nodular lesions with a rolled border and a central depression (crater) with ulceration.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that occurs on sun-exposed skin (e.g., the scalp, face, ears, dorsal aspects of the hands or arms) and predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age. The lesions typically grow back after they are scraped off. As a landscaper, this man has likely spent a lot of time working outdoors and has been frequently exposed to sun. Initially, actinic keratosis present as small, erythematous lesions with a central scale and a rough surface, giving them a sandpaper-like texture on palpation. Later, the lesions may grow and become erythematous and scaly, as seen in this patient. The risk of progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma depends on the degree of epithelial dysplasia, but it is < 1% per year. Occasionally, hyperkeratosis may turn pre-existing actinic keratosis lesions into cutaneous horns.

Actinic keratosis is usually a clinical diagnosis, although in some case a biopsy of the lesion may be necessary to distinguish it from squamous cell carcinoma. Treatment options include cryotherapy for isolated lesions, or 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod or photodynamic therapy in patients with multiple lesions, such as this man.
Image Description:

The entire hairless portion of the scalp is covered with telangiectasia, light brown papules, and yellow-brownish, hyperkeratotic plaques.

This appearance is typical of actinic keratoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus manifests as symmetric, well-demarcated papules (not crusts) that have a polygonal shape and are usually severely pruritic. Although lichen planus commonly involves the hands, as in this patient, it predominantly affects the flexor surfaces rather than the extensor surfaces.
Image Description:

Ventral wrist of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules can be seen. White reticular lines (Wickham striae) are also visible on the surface of the papules.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

F) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumor in individuals of advanced age and tends to affect the trunk, back of the hands, face and neck, and/or forearms. However, in contrast to this patient's rough, patchy lesions, the lesions are darkly pigmented papules or plaques that are soft, sharply demarcated, and appear greasy, wax-like, and 'stuck-on.'
Image Description:

Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)

Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.
questions.hint: The hand is covered with light brown papules and rough, hyperkeratotic plaques. This condition is the result of years of exposure to sunlight without protection.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless growth in his mouth. He has no other medical conditions. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 38 years but recently switched to smokeless tobacco. He drinks alcohol socially on most days of the week. Physical examination shows white patches on the oral mucosa along the gums that cannot be scraped off with gauze. The lesions have a granular texture. A combination HIV-1/2 immunoassay is negative. A biopsy of the lesion shows a marked increase in the thickness of the stratum corneum and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The pseudomembranous (common) and hyperplastic (rare) forms of oral candidiasis manifest as white lesions in the oral cavity. Chronic smoking, which can cause xerostomia and alter the balance of oral bacterial flora, is also a minor risk factor for oral candidiasis. However, the lesions of pseudomembranous candidiasis can be scraped off, unlike this patient's lesions. Hyperplastic candidiasis lesions cannot be scraped off, but they typically appear near the labial commissure, unlike the gingival lesions in this patient. Moreover, a biopsy of oral candidiasis lesions would show hyphal structures and an infiltrate of inflammatory cells.
Image Description:

There is a distinct area of white plaque on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.

This finding is characteristic oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush).

B) INCORRECT:

In-situ oral squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) can appear as a white patch that cannot be scraped off. This patient also has several risk factors for oral SCC (e.g., 50–70 years of age, male sex, smoking, alcohol use). However, a biopsy in the case of carcinoma in situ would show evidence of dysplastic changes (e.g., hyperchromatism, increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio) extending to the basement membrane of the oral epithelium. This patient has a premalignant condition that can develop into oral SCC, but there is no histological evidence of SCC at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL), which is caused by Epstein-Barr virus, manifests as white patches on the oral mucosa that cannot be wiped off with gauze, and biopsy can show marked hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis. However, the lesions of OHL are typically found on the lateral surfaces of the tongue, not the gingiva, and have a hairy or feathery rather than granular texture. Moreover, OHL lesions typically only manifest in immunocompromised patients, and there is no evidence of immunosuppression in this patient.
Image Description:

A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus typically occurs in middle-aged individuals, manifests as asymptomatic white lesions of the oral mucosa, and can show hyperkeratosis and/or parakeratosis on biopsy. However, the lesions of oral lichen planus typically appear as reticular white lines (Wickham striae), and the degree of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis on biopsy is usually minimal. Moreover, lichen planus is characterized by hypergranulosis, degeneration of the stratum basale, and saw-toothed rete ridges with lymphocytic infiltration, none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

Lacelike, white lesions on the oral mucous membrane that cannot be scraped off (Wickham striae) are visible.

This appearance is typical for oral lichen planus.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has oral leukoplakia, a relatively common precancerous condition of the oral epithelium. Smoking and alcohol consumption are important risk factors for this condition, which manifests as single or multiple asymptomatic white plaques that cannot be scraped off. Any part of the oral cavity can be affected. If untreated, leukoplakia can undergo malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. The risk of malignant transformation is higher if the white patches are nonhomogenous in appearance and/or texture (e.g., erythroleukoplakia, verrucous leukoplakia).
Image Description:

White patches that cannot be scraped off are visible on the gingiva of the lower labial sulcus (green overlay).

This finding is typical of leukoplakia, which is most commonly found in the oral cavity.
questions.hint: The oral cavity has both keratinized and nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. The stratum corneum, which is the superficial layer of keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is composed of anucleated keratinocytes. Increased thickness of this layer indicates hyperkeratosis, and the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer indicates parakeratosis.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents for his annual examination. He has a long history of sun exposure and does not use sunscreen. He says his face feels rough in areas but that there is no itch or tenderness.
Skin examination reveals numerous scaly pink papules and patches in sun-exposed areas of the face (figure). You discuss treatment choices with him, and he prefers a method he can do at home.
Which one of the following topical treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or clobetasol, would be helpful for inflammatory conditions such as atopic dermatitis but have no role in the management of actinic keratoses.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or clobetasol, would be helpful for inflammatory conditions such as atopic dermatitis but have no role in the management of actinic keratoses.

C) CORRECT:

Actinic keratoses are neoplastic lesions of the skin that are caused by ultraviolet radiation. They typically manifest as rough (hyperkeratotic) pink papules and patches in sun-exposed areas of the skin. They may remain unchanged, resolve spontaneously, or progress to invasive squamous-cell carcinoma.

Individual lesions can be treated with cryotherapy or electrodessication with curettage, but when a patient presents with numerous lesions, field therapy is preferred; this approach involves broad treatment to the area containing multiple actinic keratoses. Options include photodynamic therapy and topical treatments including fluorouracil and imiquimod among others (ingenol mebutate gel and diclofenac gel).

Key learning point: First-line treatment for a patient with numerous actinic keratoses who desires treatment with topical medications is fluorouracil cream.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical clindamycin is used to treat bacterial infections but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with skin infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical ketoconazole is used to treat fungal infections but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with skin infection.

D) INCORRECT:

In-situ oral squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) can appear as a white patch that cannot be scraped off. This patient also has several risk factors for oral SCC (e.g., 50–70 years of age, male sex, smoking, alcohol use). However, a biopsy in the case of carcinoma in situ would show evidence of dysplastic changes (e.g., hyperchromatism, increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio) extending to the basement membrane of the oral epithelium. This patient has a premalignant condition that can develop into oral SCC, but there is no histological evidence of SCC at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus typically occurs in middle-aged individuals, manifests as asymptomatic white lesions of the oral mucosa, and can show hyperkeratosis and/or parakeratosis on biopsy. However, the lesions of oral lichen planus typically appear as reticular white lines (Wickham striae), and the degree of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis on biopsy is usually minimal. Moreover, lichen planus is characterized by hypergranulosis, degeneration of the stratum basale, and saw-toothed rete ridges with lymphocytic infiltration, none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: The oral cavity has both keratinized and nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. The stratum corneum is composed of anucleated keratinocytes. Hyperkeratosis is the increased thickness of the stratum corneum, and parakeratosis is the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in this layer.

questions.text: You are seeing a 72-year-old man in your clinic for his annual examination. He has a long history of sun exposure and does not use sunscreen. He reports that his face feels rough in some areas, without itch or tenderness. On skin examination, you observe numerous scaly pink papules and patches on sun-exposed areas of his face (see figure). You discuss treatment options, and he prefers a method that can be done at home. Which one of the following topical treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or clobetasol, would be helpful for inflammatory conditions such as atopic dermatitis but have no role in the management of actinic keratoses.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as triamcinolone or clobetasol, would be helpful for inflammatory conditions such as atopic dermatitis but have no role in the management of actinic keratoses.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical ketoconazole is used to treat fungal infections but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with skin infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical clindamycin is used to treat bacterial infections but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with skin infection.

E) CORRECT:

Actinic keratoses are neoplastic lesions of the skin that are caused by ultraviolet radiation. They typically manifest as rough (hyperkeratotic) pink papules and patches in sun-exposed areas of the skin. They may remain unchanged, resolve spontaneously, or progress to invasive squamous-cell carcinoma.

Individual lesions can be treated with cryotherapy or electrodessication with curettage, but when a patient presents with numerous lesions, field therapy is preferred; this approach involves broad treatment to the area containing multiple actinic keratoses. Options include photodynamic therapy and topical treatments including fluorouracil and imiquimod among others (ingenol mebutate gel and diclofenac gel).

Key learning point: First-line treatment for a patient with numerous actinic keratoses who desires treatment with topical medications is fluorouracil cream.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of white lesions in her mouth that she first noticed 5 days ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy. She has asthma and is treated with theophylline, inhaled β-adrenergic agonists, and corticosteroids. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. Vital signs are normal. On oral examination, there are white plaques on the buccal mucosa and hard palate that are firmly adherent and cannot be scraped off. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Biopsy of the lesions is the next best step in the management of leukoplakia, which most commonly affects the oral cavity. While leukoplakia is by itself a benign lesion, it predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma. Up to 30% of leukoplakia lesions progress to carcinoma depending on appearance, demography, and follow-up time. Because of this, it is important to biopsy leukoplakia lesions to check for signs of dysplasia.

Treatment consists of smoking cessation, cryotherapy, laser ablation, or surgical excision if the lesion persists.

Key learning point: Oral leukoplakia presents as white, adherent plaques that cannot be scraped off and requires biopsy to assess for dysplasia or malignant transformation.
Image Description:

Oral cavity

Well-defined white plaques with irregular borders can be seen bilaterally on the mucosa of the soft palate.
These patches cannot be scraped off with gauze.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids would be useful for the management of aphthous stomatitis. These “canker sores” have a round to oval, crater-like appearance on yellowish-grey base and erythematous margins, unlike this patient's presentation of white plaques.

C) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole troches are a first-line therapy for mild oropharyngeal candidiasis. This patient uses inhaled corticosteroids, which are a known risk factor for developing oral candidiasis. However, candidiasis is identified by its ability to be easily scraped off. The lesions in this patient's mouth are strongly adherent, making leukoplakia a more likely diagnosis. Additionally, this patient lacks other common symptoms of candidiasis, including pain while eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth.

D) INCORRECT:

Monospot test would be used to test for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which can cause oral hairy leukoplakia. This condition also manifests as white painless plaques that cannot be scraped off. However, they tend to occur on the lateral edges of the tongue as opposed to the buccal mucosa and hard palate as seen in this patient.

Note that the EBV serology test is the diagnostic test of choice for EBV infection, as the monospot test has a high risk of false positive and false negative results.
questions.hint: This patient has white plaques of the oral mucosa that cannot be scraped off, which is typical of leukoplakia.
